conclusion: The car, labeled A, starts from the right side of the table and moves in the direction indicated by the red arrow, which is towards the left and slightly downwards.
The car's path leads directly towards the cluster of red blocks in the center of the table, so it is expected to collide with the red blocks first.

When the car collides with the red blocks, its speed will be reduced due to energy transfer to the blocks and possibly some energy dissipation. The direction of the car will also change depending on the angle of impact and the relative masses and properties of the objects. The blocks will be displaced.

After colliding with the red blocks, the car will continue to move in a new direction with reduced speed. A plausible path is towards the yellow blocks, which are located to the left and slightly downwards.
If the car is deflected towards the yellow blocks, it will then collide with one or both of the yellow blocks.
The collision with the yellow blocks will further reduce the car's speed and alter its direction. The yellow blocks will also be displaced.

After one or more collisions, the car will lose kinetic energy and eventually come to a stop when all its kinetic energy is dissipated. The car is expected to stop somewhere near or to the left of the yellow blocks.
A will collide with the red blocks and the yellow blocks, and will eventually stop near or to the left of the yellow blocks.
